Abstract: Intrinsically Disordered Proteins (IDPs) are proteins that lack a fixed three-dimensional structure, exhibiting dynamic behavior and interacting with other molecules through transient and reversible binding events. Single-molecule FÃ¶rster Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET) spectroscopy provides a unique platform to investigate the interaction dynamics of IDPs with their binding partners. This study employed single-molecule FRET to investigate the binding kinetics and dynamics of IDPs with their target proteins. Our results reveal that IDPs form disordered complexes with their target proteins, characterized by transient and reversible binding events. Molecular simulations were used to model the binding kinetics and provide insights into the structural rearrangements of IDPs during binding. The findings of this study provide new insights into the interaction dynamics of IDPs and have implications for our understanding of protein-protein interactions in various biological contexts. The results also highlight the potential of single-molecule FRET spectroscopy as a powerful tool for investigating the binding kinetics and dynamics of IDPs.
